pullRequest.title: Clarify and refactor how warnings are suppressed.
pullRequest.bodyText:
Use consistent terminology for SuppressWarnings string, prefixes, and message key.  See SourceChecker#shouldSuppressWarningStringSuppressKey for definitions.
for definitions.
Use "allcheckers:" instead of "all:" as a prefix in a warning suppression key
Renamed option -AshowSuppressWarningKeys to -AshowSuppressWarningsStrings 
Renamed meta-annotation SuppressWarningsKeys to SuppressWarningsPrefix
Renamed SourceChecker#getSuppressWarningsKeys(...) to getSuppressWarningsPrefixes
Renamed SubtypingChecker#getSuppressWarningsKeys to getSuppressWarningsPrefixes

Fixes #3356.

commit.message: Implement allcheckers as warning suppression prefix.

nodes.bodyText:
This does't seem like the right advice.
If there is no @SuppressWarningsPrefix annotation, then the implementation chooses a checker name.
I think the problem here is that the checker override getSuppressWarningsPrefixes incorrectly, and the message should say that the checker should either override it correctly, or not override it.

The use of Arrays.setAll and a lambda is shorter than this implementation and could be used here.
My preference would be to retain the arrayToLowerCase abstraction, though, because its purpose is obvious from its name, whereas I had to read the Arrays.setAll line each time I saw it to understand what it does.  Using the method is also shorter in the client.  Defining the method takes more characters than are saved at the client, but it's more important that clients are short.
Alternately, we could remove the undocumented behavior of lowercasing user-written @SuppressWarnings for the user.

The implementations of
SourceChecker.shouldSuppressWarningStringSuppressKey
SourceChecker.warnUnneededSuppressions
are very similar.
Either abstract out common logic, or eliminate one of these two methods.
(Note that there are some undesirable differences, such as the logic for permitting a user-written messagekey to be a substring of a full Checker Framework messagekey.)

The implementations of
SourceChecker.shouldSuppressWarningStringSuppressKey
SourceChecker.warnUnneededSuppressions
are very similar.
Either abstract out common logic, or eliminate one of these two methods.
(Note that there are some undesirable differences, such as the logic for permitting a user-written messagekey to be a substring of a full Checker Framework messagekey.)

How about renaming this to just "shouldSuppress" or to some other shorter name?  I find the current name a bit unwieldy, and it doesn't seem to convey more information than the shorter one.  Also, this method is not really about just keys as the method name implies.
I would rename the other overload as well.

I don't see any client that makes a varargs call to this method.  How about changing ... to [] (also in the other overload).
After doing that, would it make sense to put the array as the first argument to both variants of the call?  That seems a bit more logical to me, and makes the two overloads a bit more consistent.
I wonder if "allcheckers" should be put at the end of the list rather than the beginning, so it is less prominent in the output of -AshowSuppressWarningStrings.
